How does NEAR handle transactions and smart contract execution?
---

NEAR is a decentralized network that uses a [transaction-based model](https://docs.near.org/concepts/transactions) to process transactions and execute smart contracts. This means that transactions are processed in a sequential manner, and smart contracts are executed in a parallel manner.

Transactions are processed by a [transaction pool](https://docs.near.org/concepts/transactions/transaction-pool), which is a queue of transactions that are waiting to be processed. The transaction pool is responsible for validating transactions and ensuring that they are valid before they are processed.

When a transaction is received by the network, it is added to the transaction pool.

What are the advantages of NEAR's Proof of Stake consensus mechanism?

The Proof of Stake consensus mechanism is a consensus mechanism that uses the stake of the validators to determine the order of transactions. This mechanism is designed to prevent malicious actors from creating invalid transactions and causing the network to be unstable.

The Proof of Stake consensus mechanism has several advantages over other consensus mechanisms:

- It is more secure than other consensus mechanisms because it uses the stake of the validators to determine the order of transactions. This means that validators who have more stake will have more influence over the network and will be more likely to be selected as validators.
